instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with only 5V on ampmeter.

<SIGNAL>UPC_XB_SPI_CLK</SIGNAL> has only 0.120 on diode reading, and comparing it with other board, it seams to be low.

Should I replace <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>?

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Remove <RESISTOR>R3090</RESISTOR> and check where the low reading remains.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
It was on <SIGNAL>TBT_X_SPI_CLK</SIGNAL>, and after replacing <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> the diode readiing on <SIGNAL>TBT_X_SPI_CLK</SIGNAL> went back yo 0.605, and <SIGNAL>UPC_XB_SPI_CLK</SIGNAL> to 0.669.

<SIGNAL>UPC_XB_SPI_MISO</SIGNAL> went to 0.055 on diode reading. Can [U]<CHIP>U2890</CHIP> be bad? How can i be sure?[/U]

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Then the problem comes from <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>, or <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>.
Be sure no corrosion between J3098 pads.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Replaced <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> again, and now <SIGNAL>UPC_XB_SPI_MISO</SIGNAL> went back to 0.650 on diode reading, but still 5V only on ampmeter.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
It was <RESISTOR>R3205</RESISTOR>. I was 0.505 on diode reading, and it should be 0.650. Afetr replaced it, it started to work again.

TKS

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
It was <RESISTOR>R3205</RESISTOR>. It was 0.505 on diode reading, and it should be 0.740. After replaced it, it started to go to 20V, but only one time.

Now it is with 5V again...

Any idea?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Client said it closed it one night, and in the morning it didn't start again.

However, it had oxidation signs on the backlight area, and client said it was two years ago, and it was repaired then (can't see nothing shorted there, except some caps a bit darker, but with normal diode readings).

Now, I've replaced <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> for 3 times, and they only work on the first power on. Something is killing <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>, but I can't understand what it is.

Any idea?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Impossible to kill TBT ROM, if its power is correct.
Be sure adjacent resistors have good ohm value.
<CHIP>U2800</CHIP> may have accumulated crap underneath, or internal problems; it connects with <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> too.
Try to reball/replace it.
